document.docAuthor: Alipanah, Helen, Gielis, Cees, Sari, Alireza, Sarafrazi, Alimorad & Manzari, Shahab
document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 163 (2)
document.masterDocTitle: Phylogenetic relationships in the tribe Oxyptilini (Lepidoptera, Pterophoridae, Pterophorinae) based on morphological data of adults

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Phylogenetic relationships in the tribe Oxyptilini (Lepidoptera, Pterophoridae, Pterophorinae) based on morphological data of adults
Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

subSubSection.paragraph:
The two genera
Tomotilus and
Antarches
in the consensus trees obtained from both the EW and SAW analyses constituted a monophyletic clade (clade S, Fig. 16 ), which was the sister group of clade R ( Fig. 16 ). However, these two genera differ both in external features and genital characters. Additionally, no synapomorphic character supported their monophyly. As stated by Yano (1961) , the monotypic genus
Tomotilus
belongs to the generic group
Oxyptilus
. It is different from all other members of this group in the absence of rough scales at the base of tibial spurs; absence of apical or subapical scale teeth on the dorsum of the third lobe of the hind wing; not parallel margins of the lobes of hind wing; well-developed uncus; broad valva; and protruded globular sterigma of the female genitalia ( Yano, 1961 ). Here, it has to be mentioned that the uncus in many genera of the
Oxyptilus
generic group is developed. Moreover, although based on the original description, the scale tooth on the dorsum of the third lobe of hind wing was considered as absent ( Yano, 1961 , 1963a ), several dark scales are concentrated in the middle part and appear as a scale tooth in this area. This is a state adopted by Gielis (1993) in his phylogenetic analysis and here was also considered. Considering the absence of a scale tooth in the middle part of dorsum of the third lobe of the hind wing in
Tomotilus saitoi
, this gave it an unresolved position in the consensus tree obtained from the EW analysis ( Fig. 18 ). Gielis (1993) , based on the absence of vein R 1 in the fore wing and branching of Cu1 from the middle part of M3, showed a sister group relationship between the genus
Tomotilus and
the tribes Exelastini , Oxyptilini, Oidaematophorini, and Pterophorini together, but he later classified
Tomotilus
in Oxyptilini ( Gielis, 2003 ).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 18. Strict consensus trees of three equally most parsimonious trees obtained in the equally weighted analysis considering the absence of a scale tooth in the middle part of the third lobe of the hind wing in
Tomotilus saitoi
(state 2 was scored for character 8 and character 14 was considered as missing). Tree length = 944; consistency index = 0.4544; retention index = 0.7971.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Oxyptilus aguessei
was transferred to
Sphenarches
by Bigot & Luquet (1991) , but after describing
Antarches
and
A. luqueti , Gibeaux (1994)
placed
O. aguessei
in the newly described genus. The genus
Antarches
was recently assigned to
Exelastini ( Gielis, 2003 )
. Based on the present study, there is more evidence to sustain
Antarches
in Oxyptilini . This genus is close to
Geina
,
Paracapperia
,
Procapperia
,
Intercapperia
,
Eucapperia
, and
Capperia
based on the presence of a cone-shaped folded area at the top of the bursa copulatrix and the emergence of the ductus seminalis from the distal part of this folded area, near to the junction with the ductus bursae (characters 167 and 169). Furthermore, it is different from the members of Exelastini in the wing shape, wing venation and patterns, as well as some genital characteristics. In both
Antarches species
, valvae are as large paddles and symmetrical. It seems probable that Bigot (1964) overlooked the exact shape of the valvae in
A. aguessei
and considered them as asymmetrical. The two known
Antarches species
are very similar to each other in both external and genital characters. The differences of these two species are as follows: in
A. aguessei
, the median part of the costal process is wider than both the distal and proximal parts, and the antrum plate is not so clear, whereas in
A. luqueti
, the median part of the costal process is nearly as wide as the distal part and the antrum plate is relatively pronounced. Scoring the antrum plate as absent for the latter species provided the same tree. The results of this analysis revealed that
Tomotilus and
Antarches
were much closer to the
Oxyptilus
generic group than to
Trichoptilus
.
